The incarnation has located a relic that can weaken Strahd. However, they need the heroes to recover the item while they distract the count.
The incarnation used powerful magic to lead the heroes to Barovia so they can destroy Strahd.
The incarnation has joined the {@book Keepers of the Feather|VRGR|3|Keepers of the Feather}* and seeks to organize a siege of Castle Ravenloft.
The incarnation feels the weight of their past lives and seeks a way to end their cycle of rebirth by freeing Barovia from the Mists—or destroying it.
The incarnation falls in with a sinister group such as the {@book priests of Osybus|VRGR|3|Priests of Osybus}* and seeks to manipulate Strahd to further their organization's schemes.

The incarnation has drawn an enemy of Strahd's to Barovia, such as {@book Firan Zal'honen|VRGR|3|Firan Zal'honan}* or {@book Jander Sunstar|VRGR|3|Jander Sunstar},* hoping the rivals will slay one another.
table.name: Connection to Strahd; Hunting Strahd

table.caption: Lost Tatyana
rows: Tatyana's incorporeal spirit assembles and haunts heroes whom she believes have the best chance of defeating Strahd.
A character's friend or loved one is the incarnation of Tatyana. When the Mists claim that individual, the character is drawn into Barovia as well.
A character's own reincarnation allows Tatyana's soul to enter their body, bringing with it memories in the form of vivid dreams.

Tatyana's soul was captured by an effect similar to the {@spell magic jar} spell. Strahd or another entity hires the characters to seek out the container holding the soul, not revealing its true nature.

Tatyana's soul reincarnated as someone another Darklord covets, such as the bearer of Ankhtepot's ka in {@book Har'Akir|VRGR|3} or {@creature Elise|VRGR} in {@book Lamordia|VRGR|3} (both detailed later in this chapter).

Tatyana's soul found its way into a distant relative of Strahd, Lyssa von Zarovich. Lyssa seeks to grow more powerful and claim Castle Ravenloft for herself. Her first step to deposing Strahd was to become a {@creature vampire}. Now she needs allies.
table.name: Beyond Barovia; Lost Tatyana

table.caption: Bluetspur Adventures
rows: Characters awake within the shattered remains of a fluid-filled tube deep in Citadel Subterrene. They have no idea how they arrived there.
A cavern the characters were exploring seamlessly abuts with Bluetspur, trapping them in caves overrun with {@creature Vampiric Mind Flayer|VRGR|vampiric mind flayers} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}).
A strange message leads characters to a silvery vessel full of alien mysteries wrecked on Bluetspur's surface. The only surviving creature in the wreck is a cunning {@creature displacer beast}.

The characters find a strange but adorable creature trapped within an abandoned alien installation. The being is a lovable companion, until it reveals itself to be a {@b star spawn emissary} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Star Spawn Emissary}).
An acquaintance of the characters complains of reoccurring nightmares. The complaints stop when the dreamer is taken over by an {@creature intellect devourer}.

An inventor requests the characters' insight into a pill-sized device she extracted from her own body. As the characters examine it, the device projects a map into their minds and emits a telepathic call for help. The map leads to a {@creature mind flayer} who wants to put the God-Brain out of its misery.
A farmer hires the characters to protect his family, whom he believes—without evidence—are being abducted and returned every night.

The High Master mind flayer of Mount Grysl seeks to claim all the God-Brain knows. To do this, it creates a copy of the Apparatus (see "{@book Mordent|VRGR|3}" later in this chapter). All it needs is a relic called the Rod of Rastinon, which it wants the characters to retrieve for it.
table.name: Bluetspur Adventures

table.caption: Aberrant Evidence
rows: A needle-like device buried under someone's skin
An inexplicable crater or circle of scorched crops
A stable full of exploded livestock
An {@item antimatter rifle} (detailed in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG})
A missing person or otherworldly being transformed into a {@creature brain in a jar|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Brain in a Jar})
The damaged corpse of a {@creature vampiric mind flayer|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Vampiric Mind Flayer})
table.name: Alien Artifacts; Aberrant Evidence

table.caption: Suppressed Memories
rows: You're paralyzed on a cold table. Clicking sounds surround you. Pallid tentacles slither toward your face, each ending in gleaming surgical instruments. What are they trying to do?
Some unfamiliar reflex moves your arm. Looking, you catch a glimpse of a bruise slithering beneath your skin. What do you do?
A many-legged, ferret-like creature floats into your cell. You feel multitudes of unseen eyes upon you. What do your captors expect you to do with this? What do you do?
Rainbow storms assail the heights of a mountain so tall it seems to curve over you. You're floating over a red wasteland, just one in a line of hovering beings. What do you see ahead?
You knew a stranger. You were each other's comfort against fear and pain. Then they were taken away. What were their final words to you?
The figure hovering before you is deemed acceptable. They're lowered into a pool, where pale, slug-like beings set upon them. You float forward. Why are you deemed unacceptable?
table.name: Lost Memories; Suppressed Memories

table.caption: Noble Families and Estates
table.name: Misericordia and Other Noble Estates; Noble Families and Estates

table.caption: Borca Adventures
rows: A noble asks the characters to protect their sibling from a mysterious assassin. The killer is Nostalia Romaine, whose blood was replaced with poison by Ivana Boritsi.
A scholar requests aid in gaining access to Scholomance. This institution is Borca's elite school of magic and also home to the Rainmaker Society, which is said to control Borcan politics.
A young noble befriends the characters and introduces them to the fabulously amoral Levkarest club scene. By the night's end, a character is accused of murder.
Half the village of Leoni is arrested by the erinyes-masked Judge Ranziska and marched before Sturben's Faceless Court. The remaining villagers beseech the party to defend their families in court.
The eligible noble Vladimir Nobriskov hosts a contest for his affections. Participants turn up murdered, victims of Nobriskov's lycanthropic hunger.
A book-collecting noble seeks the party's help in finding a rare text called The Revelations of the Prince of Twilight, a tome said to teach the reader to tap into the hidden power of their shadow.
The Ocrotire family offers a sizable bounty for anyone who can capture the Lake Balaur Beast, which has escaped from the estate's oceanarium.

Members of the Ulmist Inquisition accuse the characters of crimes they haven't yet committed. They relent only if the characters undertake a mission against the {@creature Priest of Osybus|VRGR|priests of Osybus} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Priests of Osybus}).
table.name: Borca Adventures

table.caption: Ignoble Request
rows: Manufacture a business or social opportunity for the target's confidant, leaving the target isolated.
Deliver a lavish gift to the target, such as a large sculpture or a steed, at an inappropriate time.
Make the target cry in public.
Plant evidence of a crime at the target's home.
Orchestrate a false business deal, political alliance, or arranged relationship.
Make the target miss their own social event.
table.name: Ignoble Bonds; Ignoble Request

table.caption: Lethal Leverage
rows: The contact provides the characters with noteworthy gear to use during a request, then collects it afterward as evidence.
The contact conveniently "goes out of town," requesting characters report to them in writing.
The contact requests magical insurance, such as a {@spell geas} spell preventing mutual harm or committing the characters to a misrepresented act.
The contact becomes the guardian of someone close to the characters.
The contact holds a powerful magic item for the characters "so it doesn't fall into the wrong hands."
The contact has the characters act against a mutual friend "for their own good." The contact then threatens to reveal this act to the friend.
table.name: Lethal Leverage

table.caption: Carnival Adventures
rows: One of the Carnival's performers has been arrested by a local sheriff. Hermos asks the party to return the trouper, either to save them or to make them face Carnival justice.
A local hires the party to find a loved one who disappeared at the Carnival. The trail leads to a Litwick Market vendor whose trinkets turn people into their favorite animals.
The Carnival adopts a new performer escaping their family. The performer asks the party to deter family members intent on bringing them home.

The characters find a mirror holding the disembodied reflection of Tindafulus, a {@creature mage} trapped by his own reflection. He wants the party to find his duplicate, who escaped with a mysterious carnival.
table.name: Adventures in the Carnival; Carnival Adventures

table.caption: Darkon Adventures
rows: The party learns how to destroy the Heart of the Abyss, a relic held by the Order of the Guardians and hunted by a demon called the Whistling Fiend.

The {@creature night hag} Styrix has created a device called the Rift Spanner that she plans to use to escape the Domains of Dread. She just needs to transform a few hundred innocents into larvae to power it.
A ship captain offers to take the characters away from Darkon, but only after they deliver a trunk full of alchemical supplies to Madame Eris at her family estate.
Merchants hire the party as protection from the pirate ship Bountiful. Captain Damon Skragg raids not for loot, but for flesh to feed his {@creature ghoul} crew.
Researchers from the Brautslava Institute require assistants to aid in investigations into fields such as necrolinguistics and temporal archaeozoology.
Murders plague the wealthy families of Redleaf Lake. Locals seek aid from the characters, unaware the bitter dowager Damita Adler exacts a generations-old revenge from her dilapidated home.
table.name: Darkon Adventures

table.caption: Darkon's Destruction
rows: With Azalin gone, Darkon has no purpose. The Shadowfell is reabsorbing the demiplane.
Darkon is being consumed to fuel magic funneling power from Castle Avernus into the King's Tear.
The Hour of Ascension was an attack. Invaders are using the Shroud to disguise their assault.
The {@creature Priest of Osybus|VRGR|priests of Osybus} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Priests of Osybus}) are draining life from Darkon to empower the imprisoned vestige of a wicked deity.
table.name: Darkon's Destruction

table.caption: Azalin's Fate
rows: Azalin was destroyed—slain by a failed magical experiment, a rival, or the Dark Powers.
Azalin escaped the Domains of Dread and returned to his home world of Oerth.
Azalin caused an ongoing conjunction that allows him to walk free so long as Darkon is collapsing.
Azalin escaped into his past or drew multiple versions of himself into the present.
table.name: The Secret of Darkon's Doom; Azalin's Fate

table.caption: Darkon's Salvation
rows: Find or restore Azalin and return him to Darkon.
Present the Dark Powers a worthy new Darklord.
Bestow a symbol of rule upon a new Darklord.
Trick another Darklord into entering Darkon.
table.name: Darkon's Salvation

table.caption: Means to Save Darkon
rows: The Rift Spanner, a portal-making contraption
A hidden amber sarcophagus that contains the last vestige of a powerful evil being
The King's Tear, a floating anomaly or structure
The Apparatus (see "{@book Mordent|VRGR|3}" in this chapter)
The blood of Strahd von Zarovich, fundamental to the nature of the Domains of Dread
table.name: Means to Save Darkon

table.caption: Darkon Allies
rows: Irik Zal'honen, the mournful spirit of Azalin's son
The Order of the Guardians, ascetics who isolate dangerous magic and prevent supernatural ruin
Cardinna Artazas of the Eternal Order
Doctor Ingrid van Richten, a scholarly spirit who haunts Richten House near Rivalis
The Ray Agency, investigators based in Martira Bay
table.name: Darkon Allies

table.caption: Darkon Rivals
rows: Darcalus Rex and the Eternal Order
Madame Talisveri Eris and the Family
Ebbasheyth, Azalin's black shadow dragon advisor
A cursed artifact held within an Order of the Guardians monastery
Azalin's shadow, an echo of the Darklord
table.name: Darkon Rivals

table.caption: Dread in Darkon
rows: A prophecy foretells the characters' involvement in Darkon's salvation or destruction, and comes with eight unavoidable omens.
The characters were involved in the Hour of Ascension and share a Dark Gift (see {@book chapter 1|VRGR|1}).
One of the characters is the perfect vessel for a new Darklord or Azalin's rebirth.
The party is forced to work with an evil being, one from the Darkon Rivals table or another Darklord.
The dead of Darkon wish to aid the characters, flocking to them in a growing legion.
The characters suffer desperate, fractured dreams sent from mysterious allies or their future selves, warning them of calamity.
table.name: Dread in Darkon

table.caption: Darkon Finale
rows: None of Azalin's would-be inheritors are fit to become Darklord. Only by merging their spirits or making one inheritor the vessel for a hidden evil can a new Darklord arise.

The King's Tear is a dungeon-sized amber chrysalis that Azalin is using to create a new Dark Power. The characters must find the black shadow dragon Ebbasheyth and convince her to help infiltrate the floating construction and shatter it from within.

Azalin believes the only way to escape the Domains of Dread is by shattering their linchpin: the first domain, Barovia. He has escaped Darkon, but the next stage of his scheme must be stopped before he destroys all the domains.
Each of Azalin's inheritors holds a piece of the Darklord's crown. Claiming the pieces and bringing them to Castle Avernus allows Azalin's restoration or a new Darklord's ascension.
One of the characters is a clone of Azalin, created as a potential Darklord so the real Azalin could escape. The Hour of Ascension was a distraction to mislead the Dark Powers.
Azalin changed time so he never became a Darklord. The characters must follow Azalin into his past and ensure his deeds attract the Dark Powers' notice.
table.name: Darkon Finale

table.caption: Dementlieu Adventures
rows: A shrieky soprano is starring in the new production at the Port-a-Lucine Opera House. Jealous divas hire the party to figure out what magic she used to bewitch her way into a role.
A Phlegethan Hospital patient contacts the party, claiming to be the rightful Duke d'Honaire. He has a preternatural ability to bend others to his will.
The party runs afoul of the city watch and learns that their captain has been replaced by a devil who's transforming them into a brutal force.
People are being replaced by lifelike constructs, while the originals are held captive in the cellar beneath Alexandre du Cire's House of Wax. A party member is the next target.
A crusader hunting the Red Death is murdered. The culprit isn't the Red Death, but the family of a recent victim, who don't want the victim's poverty and lies to come to light.
A woman claiming to be Duchess Saidra's stepsister arrives in town and makes discreet inquiries about how to best reveal the horrible truth about the duchess: that she is a lowborn fraud.
table.name: Dementlieu Adventures

table.caption: Grand Masquerade Objectives
rows: Find a specific aristocrat at the masquerade and get information from (or to) them.
Prevent a villain from committing a crime at the masquerade.
Perform a trivial task in exchange for a favor from the hags of the Three Odd Gables, such as leaving a trinket on a mantle or filching a fruit tart.
Protect another attendee, ensuring that person isn't assassinated... or unmasked.
Use the crowd to expose people to an antidote, a curse, or important information.
Secure a private audience with Duchess Saidra.
table.name: The Grand Masquerade; Grand Masquerade Objectives

table.caption: Grand Masquerade Complications
rows: An angry guest with a costume identical to a character's accuses them of stealing the idea.
A flirtatious guest decides these interesting characters deserve to be introduced to the city's elite.
The character with the highest passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score notices a nimble-fingered guest slipping a necklace off their dance partner.
An intoxicated guest loudly confesses truths that other guests pretend not to hear.
A scream from a different part of the estate pierces the air. Everyone hushes for a moment, then immediately carries on as if nothing had happened.
Duchess Saidra enters the room, and sycophants immediately surround her.
table.name: Random Complications; Grand Masquerade Complications

table.caption: Falkovnia Adventures
rows: The party discovers a town where {@creature Zombie||zombies} have begun acting strangely: plowing fields, tarrying in shops, and congregating in the crumbling temple. What's causing this odd behavior?

In Morfenzi, Vjorn Horstman envisions an army of bestial super soldiers. He works to perfect what he calls his "primal serum," an elixir that inflicts those injected with a random form of lycanthropy. He seeks to use the characters as test subjects.
A plague strikes the slums of Lekar. Those killed by the disease rise as {@creature Zombie Plague Spreader|VRGR|zombie plague spreaders} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}).
A pack of zombie animals—predominantly wolves, ravens, and cattle—attacks work bands from Lekar and survivors upon the roads. The characters are enlisted to serve as guards.

The characters are sent to investigate a fallen star that crashed near the village of Delmunster. The village proves remarkably peaceful and free of zombies, in large part because it's populated by the {@creature Podling|VRGR|podlings} of a {@creature bodytaker plant|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}).
A character learns that an influential Talon plans to overthrow General Drakov during the next zombie assault on Lekar by sabotaging the city's defenses and admitting the zombies to the Bastion Ward.

The Jimsonweeds, a band of survivors in Silbervas, vanish after attempting to pillage Dekovan Palace. Soon after, the palace's strange lights appear among buildings formerly claimed by the lost survivors.
A knight named Gondegal attacks Talon patrols and claims she can lead common folk to a safe holdfast. None who go with her are seen again. The Talons hire the party to hunt down the knight.

The characters learn of downtrodden citizens in Lekar plotting to escape into the Mists following the next zombie siege. Are the citizens desperate noncombatants, or are they Talon agents seeking to draw out "traitors"?
On the night of the new moon, no zombie horde appears at Lekar's walls. Instead, a undead messenger arrives with a missive for General Drakov.
table.name: Falkovnia Adventures

table.caption: Zombie Siege Encounters
rows: Zombies rip apart a soldier, causing those nearby to freeze or flee.
Commoners flee the battle. A Talon attacks them, killing deserters to deter further flight.
A Talon messenger, bearing orders from General Drakov, struggles to reach a besieged gate.
A panicked Talon mage recklessly casts destructive spells, catching zombies and soldiers in the effects.
A group of commoners attempts to flee the city, revealing a hidden gap in the wall.
Zombie bodies pile up, creating a growing ramp onto a section of wall.
Zombies dig through or under the wall, allowing them to flow steadily into the city.
Zombies cause a siege weapon to fire into the city or start a conflagration.
Fighting breaks out at a building Talon priests use to treat the wounded.
Zombies break through a gate and begin scaling the portcullis beyond.
Zombies infiltrate the sewers and appear in a supposedly safe part of the city.
Masses of zombies or a botched scheme by defenders causes a wall or tower to collapse.
table.name: During the Siege; Zombie Siege Encounters

table.caption: Zombie Siege Climax
rows: Breaching the river grates, zombies pour into the city via the Zapadnost River. Drakov orders thousands of gallons of oil emptied into the sewer and then lit. The zombies burn, but flames consume the districts and the river is poisoned.

The northern district will be overwhelmed. Drakov plans to destroy the bridges crossing the river using kegs of explosive powder. This will halt the zombies but trap many soldiers and civilians on the other side.
Drakov plans to open several gates, admitting the zombies into one populated district. While the zombies feed, the district will be set aflame.
Drakov's troops round up civilians and force them out of the city, splitting the zombies' attention. This allows the Talons to shore up defenses and repel a second, less concentrated zombie attack.
table.name: Concluding the Siege; Zombie Siege Climax

table.caption: Har'Akir Adventures
rows: The priests of Ese seek adventurers to retrieve someone they condemned from the Labyrinth.
The historian Kharafek has excavated a canyon riddled with sealed tombs. She's paying laborers well but is also using them to bear the brunt of the curses the crypts conceal.
The hermits settled in River's Shelter accidentally revealed a crypt and released {@creature Mummy||mummies} that resent being disturbed.
The pyramid of a former high priest has vanished. The priests of Neb seek help finding the monument before the pharaoh notices and is displeased.
Snefru, a priest of Oru, discovers that the Bent Pyramid responds to song. She seeks aid to assemble a massive chorus to open a path inside.
The revolutionary Aliz is secretly a jackal-headed {@creature werewolf} allied with the {@creature mummy lord} Senmet. She seeks to find Ankhtepot's ka to bring the pharaoh's rule to an end.
Sute's Chosen seek help rescuing travelers missing in the Breath of the Forgotten. The party must endure the gods' tests to save them from the storm.

Nephyr, a cat-headed Child of Ankhtepot, arrives in Muhar. To motivate the living to find the pharaoh's lost treasure, each dawn she curses a number of innocents equal to the days she's spent in the city.
table.name: Har'Akir Adventures

table.caption: Ankhtepot's Soul
rows: A {@creature hawk} or {@creature giant eagle} that tirelessly circles the sun.
A canopic jar containing the pharaoh's heart hidden within a forgotten tomb
Mummified and divided-up heart-meat, a piece of which is hidden within each of the remaining loyal Children of Ankhtepot
A blessing granted to those who survive both the Breath of the Forgotten and the Breath of the False
A set of relics holy to the old gods of Har'Akir
The manifestation of a joyous song sung by Muhar's people
The soul of an innocent healer who resembles the pharaoh as he was in life
The soul of a character, perhaps one with an Echoing Soul (a Dark Gift detailed in {@book chapter 1|VRGR|1|Echoing Soul})
table.name: The Soul's Shape; Ankhtepot's Soul

table.caption: Hunt for the Ka
rows: The characters come to the attention of High Priest Rehkotep, who demands they aid her in finding the pharaoh's lost treasure or face punishment.
Revolutionaries displeased with the priests and the pharaoh search for Ankhtepot's lost treasure in hopes of gaining leverage over the ruler.
The sphinxes of Har'Akir know that Ankhtepot is close to finding his lost ka. They hope to find it first and place it outside the Darklord's reach.
A Child of Ankhtepot, either a loyal servant like Nephyr or a traitor like Senmet, tasks the characters with finding the lost ka to fulfill their own ends.
Murals or hieroglyphs within a tomb the characters discover lead to other ruins, each bearing a clue to finding the pharaoh's missing treasure.
After the characters die, Pharaoh Ankhtepot resurrects them (perhaps as reborn; see {@book chapter 1|VRGR|1|Reborn}). Their continued existence is contingent on searching for and finding his ka.
table.name: The Hunters' Role; Hunt for the Ka

table.caption: Ankhtepot Reborn
rows: Ankhtepot is now mortal, but retains all his supernatural abilities. Newly invigorated, the tyrant takes a more active role in Har'Akir's rulership, indulging in decadences and forcing the people to raise vast monuments to his newfound glory.

Ankhtepot is only briefly mortal. His body rapidly wastes away, returning him to his Undead state. Furious, he unleashes his deathless hordes, intent on transforming Har'Akir into an afterlife of his own making.
Ankhtepot is reborn and soon after dies for good. The remaining Children of Ankhtepot turn against one another, each declaring themself Pharaoh Ankhtepot II.

Ankhtepot is reborn, dies, is cursed by the gods anew, and is locked within a hidden tomb. Har'Akir falls to chaos as the land is scoured by squabbling mummies, a fruitless revolution, and harsh storms. Only by returning Ankhtepot to power can the land be saved.
table.name: The Pharaoh's Return; Ankhtepot Reborn

table.caption: Hazlan Adventures
rows: Hazlik's apprentice Eleni charmed the ancient albino {@creature purple worm} Gravedrinker, using it as a weapon against any who oppose her master. When the worm breaks free of her control, Eleni seeks aid with recapturing it before Hazlik finds out.

Castoff magical creations litter the dry lake bed called Obsession's End. A sapient war machine or an {@creature iron golem} escapes the midden and asks the party to help it find a way to live an ordinary life.

Innumerable {@creature Gremishka|VRGR|gremishkas} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Gremishka}) collect in caves along what's known as the Gnawing Path. The creatures plot to overwhelm Sly-Var and will pass through Toyalis in the process. Members of both communities request exterminators.

A cult forms around the Philosopher's Egg, an eight-story citrine egg perched atop a mesa in the region called Seething. The cultists hunt for someone who has never been touched by magic to release the unborn antimagic entity within.

One of Hazlik's apprentices sends multiple groups to capture a {@b star spawn emissary} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5|Star Spawn Emissary}) that emerged from a meteor in Moonstone Valley. But the shape-shifter disappears, slipping in among its would-be captors.
An apprentice of Hazlik yearns to explore the bottomless pit known as Gluttonkettle. He needs a test crew for a vehicle he's devised to traverse impossible distances.

A magically talented commoner is kidnapped and forced to become a wizard's apprentice. Their family hires the characters to retrieve them, but the kidnappee has quickly adjusted to the decadent life of an amoral wizard.

The moon over Hazlan shatters and plummets toward the ground. Whether caused by a mighty spell gone awry or a domain-spanning illusion, the sight throws Toyalis into chaos. Residents demand that the characters help them flee the disaster.
One of Hazlik's apprentices needs agents to search for a suspected fountain of youth said to have formed among the innumerable magical toxins polluting the swamp known as the Brew.
Hazlik knows his domain's days are numbered. He attempts to use the characters to recreate the living portal that first brought him to Hazlan, either as its creators or its raw materials.
table.name: Hazlan Adventures

table.caption: Hazlan Wild Magic
rows: The character causes a random effect from the {@table Wild Magic Surge|phb|Wild Magic Surge} table in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}.
The character is {@condition frightened} of all creatures until the end of their next turn.

A number ({@dice 2d4}) of the Staring Cats of Uldun-dar appear within 30 feet of the character. These sapient, hyperdimensional {@creature Cat||cats} have uneven numbers of eyes and are not hostile, but they ominously share reports on how the character died in multiple parallel dimensions. The cats vanish after the character's next long rest.
The character and the creature nearest them both teleport up to 60 feet to random unoccupied spaces of the DM's choice. When they reappear, they are covered in harmless ectoplasm.
The character broadcasts their surface thoughts for 1 round, as if all creatures within 30 feet of them had cast {@spell detect thoughts} targeting them.
A spectral Eye of Hazlik appears, hovering over the character for 1 hour. The eye functions as detailed in the "{@book The Eye of Hazlik|VRGR|3|The Eye of Hazlik}" section.

A portal similar to that created by {@spell arcane gate} opens within 10 feet of the character. It connects to another portal somewhere in Hazlan. The portal remains open for 1 hour, during which creatures from either side can pass through.

A shrieking, skinless, many-limbed horror that has the statistics of (and vaguely resembles) a {@creature unicorn} appears within 30 feet of the character. It is hostile to them, vanishing after 1 minute.
The character casts {@spell fireball} as a 5th-level spell centered on themself using Charisma as the spellcasting ability. Screams and laughter emanate from the flames.

A fog cloud appears, centered on the character. The effect is similar to a {@spell fog cloud} spell and lasts for 10 minutes. The DM can choose to have the fog affect creatures as if they'd entered the Mists.
table.name: Hazlan Wild Magic

table.caption: I'Cath Adventures
rows: A desperate local needs medicine for a sick spouse, but the only merchant in Gwai-Huit Center with the necessary herbs demands fresh fruit from the Gemstone Gardens. The local entreats the characters to infiltrate the {@creature jiangshi|VRGR}-haunted park (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}).
A child has gone missing on the streets of I'Cath. The child's parents plead with the characters to find the youngster before dusk.
A {@creature spy} known as a criminal in I'Cath's dream city is imprisoned and tormented every time he falls asleep. He begs for the characters' aid to help keep him awake.
A group of {@creature Bandit||bandits} waylay anyone who passes through their territory, demanding fresh meat for passage. Trapped locals seek help in moving through the gang's territory.
A melancholy elf is unable to enter Tsien Chiang's dream to join his family. He entreats the characters to help him find a way.

A {@creature jiangshi|VRGR} approaches the characters and asks them to locate one or more of her lost family members within the dream city. She's worried about what's become of her family—their bodies should be in the city, but she's lost track of them.

A family in the Mansions made offerings of food and remembrances to placate a hungry {@creature ghost}. This has attracted dozens of other ghosts. The family seeks help placating the undead mouths they can't feed.

Tsien Chiang's library in the Palace of Bones holds secrets about the border between dreams and reality. The characters must infiltrate the palace, find the information they need, and escape before Tsien Chiang returns at dawn.

A desperate {@creature veteran} wakes from the dream and attempts to set I'Cath on fire, believing it's better for everything to burn than to live a lie. The characters must choose how to contend with the murderous arsonist.

All but one of Tsien Chiang's daughters have gone missing—and the remaining daughter is either Tsien Seu-Mei or Tsien Lei-An, neither of whom can speak. This daughter crosses the party's path and silently begs for help.
table.name: I'Cath Adventures

table.caption: Kalakeri Adventures
rows: {@creature Bandit||Bandits} takes over the village of Neelakurinji, claiming Ramya or Arijani as their leader. In truth they serve neither and are opportunistically robbing those who fear disobeying the factions. An escaped villager entreats the characters for help.
The {@creature stone giant} guru Jalendu claims to know a path to religious enlightenment. Those who fail to prove their devotion to his teachings turn up {@condition petrified}.
The sea boils around an ancient, submerged ruin called the Drowned Altar. With constant upheaval, no one has performed the rites necessary to placate what dwells in the deep.
Dozens of servants were hired to help host a grand gala thrown by Arijani. The event was a success, but none of the servants returned home. Their families entreat the characters to seek answers.

The rare ralvanji spice has miraculous medicinal properties, but by royal edict it is grown only in the gardens of the Cerulean Citadel. Estavan, a mysterious {@creature oni} merchant, offers to pay good money for the spice and even more for the seeds.
A parent asks the characters to bring their runaway teenager home, not knowing their child joined Ramya's army, died, and returned as a {@creature wight}.

Reeva employs the party to find the forbidden ruins of Bahru, said to lie somewhere in the Ashwagangha Mountains. She believes her ancestors imprisoned a powerful force there, which she hopes to awaken and bend to her service.

The shadows of people in Meenakara are disappearing, and the shadow-bereft soon sicken and die. A local leader claims that the strange plague's cure lies among the hidden isles known as the Ashram of {@book Niranjan|VRGR|3|Niranjan} (detailed in "{@book Other Domains of Dread|VRGR|3}" later in this chapter).
A {@creature commoner} begs the characters to prove their sibling's loyalty to Ramya. Time is short, since the sibling was arrested and taken to the Tower of Traitors to face execution.
Ramya desires a consort to cement her rulership and bring stability to the kingdom. A character who is a capable warrior catches her attention.
table.name: Kalakeri Adventures

table.caption: Renown in Kalakeri
rows: Attaining victory over a rival through martial skill
Attaining victory over a rival through duplicity
Completing a mission assigned by the faction
Gaining a rich or powerful ally for the faction
Offering rare occult lore to Reeva
Recovering Arijani or Reeva's skull from the Tower of Traitors
Ousting foes from the Cerulean Citadel
Being caught aiding a rival faction's agenda
Discovering a faction leader's true form
table.name: Renown in Kalakeri

table.caption: Loyalist Benefits
rows: Learning the location of the bulk of Ramya's armies
Learning where a particular skull is in the Tower of Traitors
Learning where a specific soldier in Ramya's army is stationed
Gaining an audience with Maharani Ramya
Pardoning someone accused of being a traitor
Gaining command of a contingent of Undead soldiers to fulfill a mission
Convincing the faction to heed advice
Convincing Ramya to relinquish a skull from the Tower of Traitors or dismiss a soldier from her army
Convincing the faction to heed advice seemingly counter to its interests
table.name: Benefits of Renown; Loyalist Benefits

table.caption: Rebel Benefits
rows: Learning if a wealthy individual has been courted by the rebels in the past month
Learning where Arijani and Reeva are encamped
Gaining a private audience with both Arijani and Reeva
Gaining a private audience with either Arijani or Reeva
Obtaining an invitation to one of Arijani and Reeva's galas
Convincing the faction to heed advice
Convincing the faction to heed advice seemingly counter to its interests
Obtaining an invitation to one of Arijani and Reeva's private feasts
Convincing Reeva to reveal secrets hidden under the Cerulean Citadel
table.name: Benefits of Renown; Rebel Benefits

table.caption: Kartakass Adventures
rows: The characters arrive in Kartakass and immediately meet a friendly local: Harkon Lukas.
A foe carries an invitation to Harmonia's Crystal Club. If the characters visit, they find themselves the only non-lycanthropes in the crowd.
A set dresser in Medria used "tamed"{@creature Mimic||mimics} during a stage production. Now the audience is trapped inside a theater overrun by the monsters.
The party investigates a murder in Emherst. The victim is an actor who played a character murdered daily in the ongoing immersive play.
Akriel Lukas hires the party to "borrow" her father's violin so she can accurately model her own violin, Sundered Heart, from it.
A scholar named Radaga seeks the characters' aid in recovering a mysterious relic—an ancient crown—from a skeleton-haunted canyon in the Martello Hills.

The party is invited to participate in a fighting tournament in the goblin-overrun hills known as the Catacombs. Upon arriving, they find that {@creature Goblin||goblins} organized the event under the oversight of the flamboyant {@creature gladiator} Nym Pymplee.

A brewer in Harmonia hires the party to deliver a cart of meekulbrau—a local berry wine that soothes the throat and improves vocal performances. A band of thieves hijacked the last two deliveries, and the brewer wants to make sure this latest delivery reaches its buyer, Harkon Lukas.
table.name: Kartakass Adventures

table.caption: Favors for Harkon Lukas
rows: Harkon is expected to debut a new song, "Just Like the Wind," but his backup performers and entourage are missing. The Darklord asks for the characters to fill in as entertainers and personal security.
Harkon expects to be attacked by a toxic former student or lover at a public event. The Darklord asks the party to intercept this stalker.
Harkon feigns fear of being mobbed by fans. The Darklord asks the party to disguise him and escort him to an event.
In the wild, Harkon's entourage is slain by wolves or by bandits. If the party saves him, the Darklord feigns helplessness and asks to travel with them.
table.name: Meeting the Darklord; Favors for Harkon Lukas

table.caption: Lamordia Adventures
rows: Sapient lab animals escape Ludendorf University and need help finding a new home. One, however, is eager to improve upon its form and the forms of its fellows.

Medical student Emil Bollenbach strives to craft revolutionary {@creature Flesh Golem||flesh golems}, such as ones made entirely of doppelgangers or beholders. His patrons enlist the party to aid his research.

A murderous, jaundiced whale is hunting Ludendorf's ships. The superstitious Captain Furschter of the city's navy asks the party to learn why by seeking Winter's Mouth, a crack in the ice where the sea supposedly whispers its secrets.
Three brilliant Ludendorf University students compete to become Dr. Mordenheim's new assistant. Each seeks the party's assistance in ensuring they're chosen for the opportunity.

A wave of warped monstrosities is preparing to assault Neufurchtenburg. The metallurgists at the Giesbrecht Automatic Armaments company have created a new weapon or vehicle that could save the town, but they need someone to test it.

Ruprekt Schaller stood to inherit his dying father's factory in Ludendorf. Instead, Udo Schaller paid assassins to murder his son and had his brain transplanted into Ruprekt's young body, with the help of Dr. Mordenheim. Udo's daughter and sole surviving heir, Varissa Schaller, wants to avenge her brother's murder and begs the party to help destroy her father.

Prospectors seeking rare gas pockets discover numerous well-preserved bog mummies dating back to Lamordia's ancient druidic peoples. They seek help when the mummies vanish and undead animals begin terrorizing their camp.
Baron von Aubrecker writes to the party, asking them to recover the body of a "relative" from the Haifisch, a shipwreck impaled on a spire of ice.

The Sleeping Beast is experiencing an increasing number of earthquakes. The overseers of the Pulstein Mine call for aid, believing that strange creatures are causing the quakes to steal the "marrowstone" they're mining.
Scholars at Ludendorf University learn of the Unbreakable Heart and claim a monster stole it. The characters and dozens of other hunters are sent to the Isles of Agony to recover the device.
table.name: Lamordia Adventures

table.caption: Serving Dr. Mordenheim
rows: The doctor desires a cutting-edge discovery from a factory in Neufurchtenburg. To acquire it, she has kidnapped the factory owner's family and put the characters' consciousnesses into their bodies. Until the characters deliver the discovery, she holds their bodies and the family's brains in cold storage.

Wishing to spy on Ludendorf University, Mordenheim mounts the characters' heads onto suits of {@creature animated armor}. The characters will get their bodies back when they return with the information the doctor desires.

Agents of Baron von Aubrecker attack Schloss Mordenheim and wreak considerable damage. Dr. Mordenheim places the characters' brains into {@creature Flesh Golem||flesh golems} and sets them loose to punish the baron.

Dr. Mordenheim wants {@creature Elise|VRGR} found and returned. Using various monster parts, she creates unique hunter bodies with the statistics of {@creature Flesh Golem||flesh golems} or {@b} other monsters. She places the characters' minds into these bodies, promising to restore them when they bring her {@creature Elise|VRGR}.
table.name: Mordenheim's Designs; Serving Dr. Mordenheim

table.caption: Mordent Adventures
rows: An alchemist discovers a way to "burn" spirits to provide fuel for magical fire. Several spirits seek the party's aid in preventing their second death.
A {@creature noble} seeks help as an undead ancestor tries to prevent the {@creature noble}'s marriage to an "unsuitable" partner.
The spirits of two lovers whose families prevented their union begin exacting revenge on the living.
A pair of rival fiends, Athos and Diche, break loose from idols in the collection at Heather House. Members of the Weathermay family call for aid.

The citizens of the village of Crawford spread tales of a gigantic {@creature raven}. Sheriff Perkins hires the characters to hunt down the creature, which is actually a {@creature wereraven|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}) protecting the community from a greater threat.
A curse has afflicted Westcote Manor for a hundred years. The surrounding bog encroaches on the house, and howling bog hounds draw ever closer to the estate's beleaguered lord.
The baronet of a small estate is forced to commit increasingly heinous crimes each day or face unspeakable torment at the hands of his ghostly ancestors, who suffered under the same curse.
Someone has rebuilt the infamous Apparatus and is using it to transpose vicious souls into the bodies of mild-mannered citizens of Mordentshire.
table.name: Mordent Adventures

table.caption: Ghost's History
rows: The ghost died so recently that they might not yet fully realize they are dead.
The ghost died recently enough that people who knew them in life are still around.
The ghost died years ago, and few people who knew them in life are still alive.
The ghost died a generation ago; folks remember rumors or stories told about the person's life.
The ghost died multiple generations ago, and only local folklore or histories preserve their memory.
The ghost died a very long time ago, and no one knows anything about their history.
table.name: Ghost's History

table.caption: Tragic Elements
rows: The ghost aches from a broken heart.
The ghost interferes with the romantic life of their victim.
The ghost was falsely accused and convicted of a crime.
The ghost makes an innocent person appear to be guilty of the ghost's crimes.
In life, the ghost was cut off by family members and denied a rightful inheritance.
The ghost refuses to acknowledge any living heirs as family members and tries to prevent these heirs from inheriting what is rightly theirs.
Society shunned the ghost unfairly in life.
Association with the ghost causes their living victim to be shunned by society.
In life, the ghost's efforts to do good led them to be cursed by a hag, fiend, or powerful spirit.
The ghost foils their victim's efforts to do good.
table.name: Tragedy; Tragic Elements

table.caption: Romantic Elements
rows: The ghost hopes to be reunited with another ghost—the spirit of someone they loved in life.
The ghost haunts someone they loved in life, who still returns that love.
The ghost haunts a place they loved in life, perhaps their home or a memorial to one they lost.
The ghost haunts someone they loved in life, who is trying to move on.
The ghost haunts someone who looks like a person the ghost loved in life (possibly a descendant of that person).
A person who loved the ghost in life refuses to let the spirit leave.
The ghost was murdered by someone they loved in life.
The ghost seeks vengeance on someone who spurned them in life.
table.name: Romance; Romantic Elements

table.caption: Richemulot Adventures
rows: At the command of Jacqueline Renier, {@creature Swarm of Rats||swarms of rats} nightly slip into homes and murder the resident cats. Distraught pet owners entreat the characters for aid.
A desperate rogue seeks the characters' aid when the rest of her band is trapped within the abandoned Fiox Estate by a haywire security system.

A band of students plot a revolution against Jacqueline Renier in the valley called Assassin's Echo. They're convinced one among them is a traitor but don't realize there's a {@creature wererat} in their midst.

A constable requests the characters' aid in solving murders in which the victims have been drained of blood. The murderer is a {@creature strigoi|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}) that haunts a sunken chapel in the swamp known as the Gardens.

Doctor Temator of Mortigny believes she can create a cure for the Gnawing Plague and enlists the characters to find subjects who have never had the disease. Rumors soon spread that the doctor and characters are actually spreading the plague.

Louise Renier seeks the characters' aid in infiltrating a ball Jacqueline is holding at Chateau Delanuit. She aims to infuriate Jacqueline so that she reveals her {@creature wererat} nature before her guests.
table.name: Richemulot Adventures

table.caption: Stage Two Encounters
rows: The character avoids direct contact with anyone who might be infected.
How many people brush up against the character as they push through the crowds? The character must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
A nearby person turns and coughs directly on the character, who must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.

A {@creature rat} scurries across the character's foot. If the character isn't wearing metal armor, it scratches them and they must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
A sobbing child is separated from their parents in a crowd. A character who physically interacts with the child must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
A cutpurse tries to pick the character's pocket. If the character tries to physically stop the criminal, they must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
table.name: Stage Two: Outbreak; Stage Two Encounters

table.caption: Stage Three Encounters
rows: A dead body lies in the character's path. A character who touches the body must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
A retching {@creature commoner} tries to grapple the character, begging for any help. Anyone the commoner touches must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
Three Casques Silencieux ({@creature animated armor}) gesture for the character to get indoors immediately. They turn hostile if the character resists.
Several mangy {@creature Giant Rat||giant rats} attack. Anyone bitten by a giant rat must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.

A {@creature swarm of rats} shadows the character as they travel. If confronted, the swarm attacks. Anyone bitten by the rats must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.

A young, well-heeled couple cavorts openly, oblivious to the quarantine. These {@creature Wererat||wererats} don't reveal their true nature unless they must, and then only to blend in with the swarms of rats.
table.name: Stage Three: Illness; Stage Three Encounters

table.caption: Stage Four Encounters
rows: A desperate group of {@creature Commoner||commoners} tries to break through a sealed gate to escape quarantine. Anyone who tries to aid or deter them must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or contract the Gnawing Plague.
Three thieves attack someone who cries out for help. If a character intervenes, all four thieves reveal themselves to be {@creature Wererat||wererats} and attack.

A squad of Casques Silencieux ({@creature animated armor}) marches through the street. If the Casques Silencieux spot a character, they try to force the character into a home where the residents are all dead.

The character spots several rats in an alley using trash to enact a miniature courtroom drama. If a character interrupts or is critical of the rats' play, the rats become a {@creature swarm of rats} and attack.

The character notices a {@creature giant rat} about to throw alchemist's fire at an inhabited home. If they intervene, the rat flees. Whether or not it escapes, the character's lodgings are soon the target of arson.
A celebration takes place in a nearby house. Six {@creature Wererat||wererats} openly cavort in hybrid form, dancing and carousing with the corpses of the home's former owners.
table.name: Stage Four: Pestilence; Stage Four Encounters

table.caption: Tepest Adventures
rows: Toxic, vision-inducing fungi taint the ruined village of Briggdarrow. Recently, homesteaders outside Viktal discovered the fungus on their properties and claim it's being spread by strange fungus-covered bipeds (myconids).
A hermit who once lived in the abandoned fortress on Cas Island hires the party to retrieve an heirloom she left behind. But she warns that the Avanc, a dangerous lake monster, swims nearby.
A shepherd's youngest child went missing after a sinkhole opened in a nearby pasture, revealing a glowing cavern that leads into the tunnels of Arak.
The Parrish family fled Viktal in fear of Mother. They seek help revealing her malice to their former neighbors before she finds them.
Mother's Minders nail wicker dolls over the doors of a dozen houses in Viktal. Soon after, both the dolls and the inhabitants of those houses vanish.

A druid seeks aid in reclaiming their people's holy site from an ancient, evil {@creature treant} called Blightroot. The druid doesn't mention that the surrounding forests are a clonal colony of the villainous plant.

A grieving villager begs the characters to take their deceased loved one to the Cauldron, a pool said to restore life to a corpse bathed in its waters. The villager says nothing of the terrible price the pool's magic exacts.
Two young lovers go missing from Viktal. One is found days later, unable to remember anything, aged fifty years, and desperate for help to find their partner.
A character's reflection on the water warns of impending doom. The image insists they find the Seer's Glass, which can reveal the past and future.
A strange old woman claims to have lost her child and begs the characters for help. Thus disguised, Lorinda hopes to have the party track down her runaway Laoirse.
table.name: Tepest Adventures

table.caption: Sights in Viktal
rows: Locals weave flowers into crowns and sew cuts of meat into cloaks, creating traditional garb for an upcoming festival.
Most children in town are hexbloods (see {@book chapter 1|VRGR|1|Hexblood}). Evasive locals refuse to say why.
Villagers harvest wings and chrysalises from caged moths, which are powdered and used to make "shift spice"—a pervasive ingredient in local dishes.
A group of young people dramatically sob at the window of an old woman, who tosses horned wicker dolls to those who sob loudest.
A local fisher teaches knife-wielding youngsters how to debone live eels and create festive "elver-crowns," a grim local decoration.
With adult approval, youngsters affix hornlike sticks to a terrified animal's head.
A lovingly carved door or mural depicts a woman's face made of moth wings, watching over an explicitly detailed scene of butchery or surgery.
Villagers sing and dance in a circle around someone undergoing a ritual to have their left eye removed.
table.name: Welcome to Viktal; Sights in Viktal

table.caption: Tithe Events
rows: Crooked Joust. Participants use stilts strapped to their arms and legs to topple one another.
Powrie Chase. Pursuers dress as wicked faeries, donning tattered red cloaks and using sharp darts in a game of tag.
Lost Siblings. Blindfolded participants identify other players by touching their hair.
Gossamer Glutton. Whoever eats the most live moths wins.
Hungry Sister. A dozen players with a rope tied around them try to stop someone from getting past them and stealing a pear from a bowl.
A dried length of pear skin
Never Naughty. Participants take turns flattering three elderly villagers, who decide who wins and who gets paddled.
table.name: Tithe Events

table.caption: Valachan Adventures
rows: The Oselo joyously adopt a new member into their community, but the ceremony erupts in strife when Chakuna appears and demands that all newcomers participate in the Trial of Hearts.

Shuaran warriors seek help in slaying a massive {@creature saber-toothed tiger} killing their people. They don't mention that they recently lost the Cat of Felkovic, a sentient magic item similar to a {@item figurine of wondrous power} that conjures a feline killer.

A sapient {@creature giant spider} emerges from the caverns known as the Council of the Whip Spider. It demands that the Oselo provide it a sacrifice, or every arachnid in Valachan will attack the village.
The {@creature tyrannosaurus rex} called Mother Heartless rampages from the Forest of Fossils, incensed by something amiss in her hunting grounds.
The {@creature lizardfolk} of the lakes surrounding the Anquara Plateau discover a submerged ruin and unleash an {@creature aboleth} that now holds them in thrall.
Beast-shaped {@creature Treant||treants} animate and lay siege to Pantara Lodge, obeying Urik von Kharkov's will.
The merchant ship Zodiac runs aground on Kiru Island. The sailors seek help salvaging other shipwrecks and escaping back to sea—preferably before Chakuna notices them.
A pack of {@creature Displacer Beast||displacer beasts} washes up dead in Sangui Cove. An enraged Chakuna prowls the jungle, slaying anyone she suspects of being involved.
table.name: Valachan Adventures

table.caption: Valachan Hunt Complications
rows: Chakuna appears and attacks. Roll a die. If you roll an even number, this occurs during another complication and you can roll again on this table. If you roll an odd number, Chakuna attacks suddenly without another complication.

Dense foliage, swampy ground, clouds of insects, or thick fog slows the party's travel to a crawl. The party chooses one character, who must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check or the party's travel speed is reduced by half for the next hour (this is in addition to any speed reduction from {@quickref difficult terrain||3}).

The area is riddled with traps set by Chakuna. A random character must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check or fall into a {@trap pits||spiked pit} (see the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).
{@creature Chuul||Chuuls}, {@creature Vine Blight||vine blights}, or {@creature Zombie Plague Spreader|VRGR|zombie plague spreaders} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}) ambush the party.

The characters find a tree bound in rope. One or more withered, oversized hearts hang from cords attached to its branches. Roll a die. If you roll an even number, the hearts look grim but are harmless. If you roll an odd number, the {@dice 1d6} hearts have the statistics of gnashing {@creature Death's Head|VRGR|death's heads} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}) and attack.

Clouds of insects, persistent leeches, or other parasites torment the party. Each character must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check or gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}. Creatures immune to disease suffer no ill effects from the parasites.

The party encounters a {@creature druid}, {@creature green hag}, or {@creature displacer beast} that is not part of the hunt. If a character succeeds on a DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check, that creature shows them a route that allows them to move at double their speed for the next hour and avoid rolling on this table at the end of that time.
An individual or a group of competitors—{@creature Gladiator||gladiators}, {@creature Scout||scouts}, or {@creature Tribal Warrior||tribal warriors}—attempts to ambush the party.
Whispers in the Druidic language issue from the boughs of trees and cracks in the earth. They repeat one word: Blood.

A desperate competitor appears. Roll a die. If you roll an even number, the competitor is gravely wounded, incoherent, and suffering from hallucinations. If you roll an odd number, the competitor offers to help the party break the trial's rules and is struck dead by an arrow from the forest seconds later.
Dinosaurs, {@creature Giant Poisonous Snake||giant poisonous snakes}, or {@creature Hydra||hydras} attack the party.

A rope bridge provides the only method of crossing a river or ravine. Each character must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check to cross the bridge or fall 60 feet into the jungle or water below. The bridge has AC 11, 16 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.
The party discovers an overgrown ruin. A character who succeeds on a DC 18 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check spots a relief carving of a wicked-looking figure ripping out its own heart.
A random character must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check or fall into {@book quicksand|DMG|5|Quicksand} (see the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).
{@creature Panther||Panthers}, {@creature Displacer Beast||displacer beasts}, or werepanthers ({@creature Weretiger||weretigers}) attempt to ambush the party.
The characters discover the corpse of a competitor. Roll a die. If you roll an even number, the corpse has a {@item potion of healing}. If you roll an odd number, the corpse's heart has been removed.

The party chooses one character who must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. On a failed check, the party becomes lost. It takes the characters 1 hour to realize they are {@dice 1d4} miles away from their assumed location in a disadvantageous direction.
table.name: Valachan Hunt Complications

table.caption: Strangers in the Mists
rows: Someone from another world who's just been drawn into a domain by the Mists
Someone fleeing the Darklord of another domain
A raven carrying a message from the Keepers of the Feather
Curious members of the Keepers of the Feather led by a {@creature wereraven|VRGR} (see {@book chapter 5|VRGR|5}) in disguise
A spirit that cries out before being yanked back into the Mists, leaving behind a Mist talisman
table.name: Travelers in the Mists; Strangers in the Mists

table.caption: Keeper Adventures
rows: Keepers invite the characters to a social gathering where fortunes are told and attendees sample rare imported mumia—powdered mummy.
A Keeper delivers a letter to the characters that arrived by raven. The message has no sender.
Orphir Brindletop, a Kalakeri gnome occultist, is surprised to meet one of the characters, as he received a message for them in a séance long ago.
The characters are invited to help a Keeper stake out a graveyard in hopes of spotting a legendary creature said to dwell there.

The party is hired to collect a parcel from the Blue Water Inn in the Barovian town of Vallaki, which is secretly run by wereravens. They must not open the package and must get it out of Barovia swiftly.
A character glimpses a raven-like figure. When they investigate, they find only the mysterious talisman that it left behind.
table.name: Keeper Adventures

table.caption: Feywild Weather
rows: Bloemenbloesems regenen uit een hemel gevuld met sprankelende, pastelkleurige wolken.
Een groots sprookjesachtig drama speelt zich af in de lucht als een stilistisch weergegeven illusie of een wervelend noorderlicht.
Het regent kleine vruchtentaartjes. Ze vallen langzaam en verdwijnen net voor ze de grond raken. Als je ze uit de lucht vangt en opeet, zijn ze heerlijk.
De mist rolt binnen en haalt onschuldige streken uit met de personages. Ze krijgen mistsnorren, mistwenkbrauwen en mistpruiken in allerlei stijlen - en misschien zelfs mistmantels of mistgezellen.
De sneeuw begint te vallen, en de vlokken worden steeds groter. Vlokken zo groot als dinerborden, wagenwielen, en zelfs een waterrad vallen, maar ze zijn zo licht als een veertje.

De lucht vult zich met iriserende bubbels die lui op de grond vallen. Giechelende elfenkinderen achtervolgen en laten de bellen knappen, maar draaien {@condition invisible} en vluchten als ze worden aangesproken of benaderd.
Een zilveren regen verheft de geesten en brengt een lied in elk hart dat het aanraakt.

Er waait een gierende wind door het gezelschap, en elk lid van het gezelschap moet een {@dice d8} gooien. Van iedereen die een 8 gooit, wordt een snuisterij of een ander klein, niet-magisch voorwerp (zoals een munt) gestolen door de weergeesten.
table.name: Feywild Weather

table.caption: Feywild Guide Identities
rows: Vriendelijke boskabouter (gebruik het {@creature scout} stat block, maar verander zijn grootte in Klein)
Sombere bos elf druïde (gebruik de {@creature druid} stat block)
Overdreven voorzichtig {@creature treant sapling|wbtw} (zie hoofdstuk 1 van The Wild Beyond the Witchlight voor het stat blok)
Giggly goblin warlock (gebruik het {@creature cult fanatic} stat block, maar verander zijn grootte in Small)
table.name: Feywild Guides; Feywild Guide Identities

table.caption: Feywild Guide Quirks
rows: Altijd terugblikken en dingen vergelijken met "de goede oude tijd"
Kan geen leugen vertellen zonder eerst met hun neus te wiebelen
Houdt van eten en is niet kieskeurig over wat ze eten
Op een geheime zoektocht waar ze niet over mogen praten, behalve om anderen eraan te herinneren dat ze "op een geheime zoektocht" zijn
Bang voor iets alledaags, zoals hoogtes, gesloten ruimtes, of blote handen en voeten
Draagt een koffer vol pruiken, vorken, as, glazen bollen, achtergelaten schoenen, of iets anders vreemds
Vol met volkswijsheden die meestal beginnen met, "Papa zei altijd..." of "Mama zei altijd..."
table.name: Feywild Guides; Feywild Guide Quirks

table.caption: Fey Desires for Greater Contracts
rows: Om het volgende kind in je familie te nemen en op te voeden in de Feywild
De voltooiing van drie queesten, die u elk moet goedkeuren voordat het contract wordt gevormd
De ondergang of ondergang van de gezworen vijand van de Fey
Een kostbaar voorwerp (zoals een zeldzaam, zeer zeldzaam of legendarisch magisch voorwerp) dat is gestolen door of toebehoort aan de gezworen vijand van de Fey
Een kunstvoorwerp dat als onbetaalbaar wordt beschouwd, zoals een beroemd schilderij dat in een museum hangt
Je jeugd (die de Fey kunnen oogsten en aan een ander wezen schenken)
table.name: Price of a Contract; Fey Desires for Greater Contracts

table.caption: Fey Desires for Lesser Contracts
rows: Een snuisterij met een grote sentimentele waarde
Gezelschap (je blijft in het gezelschap van de Fey voor een afgesproken periode)
De herinnering aan je eerste kus
De veer in je stap of de glinstering in je ogen
Uw naam (waarbij u voor uzelf een nieuwe moet kiezen)
table.name: Price of a Contract; Fey Desires for Lesser Contracts

table.caption: Breaking a Greater Contract
rows: Je kan niet spreken of spreuken uitspreken met verbale componenten. Als je probeert te spreken, blaf je in plaats daarvan als een ezel.
Je verandert op magische wijze in een uil. Je behoudt je talen, je spraakvermogen en je mentale vermogens (Intelligentie, Wijsheid en Charisma). Voor de rest heb je de statistieken van een uil.
Je kunt je niet afstemmen op magische voorwerpen. Als je momenteel bent afgestemd op een of meer magische voorwerpen, eindigt je afstemming op die voorwerpen onmiddellijk.

Een ijzeren doorn zit op magische wijze vast in je borst. Elke dag voel je hem dichter bij je hart komen. Als dit effect niet binnen 3 dagen wordt beëindigd, sterf je en kun je {@dice 5d12} dagen niet meer tot leven worden gewekt.
table.name: Breaking a Contract; Breaking a Greater Contract

table.caption: Breaking a Lesser Contract
rows: Je uiterlijk wordt meer pad-achtig (wratachtige huid, bolle ogen, grote mond, en met zwemvliezen vergroeide vingers). Deze transformatie heeft geen speleffecten.
Je ruikt naar moerasgas. Geen bad kan je van deze stank verlossen.
Je schaduw komt niet overeen met je bewegingen, wat andere wezens verontrustend vinden.
Je lijkt meer op een rat (kraalogen, snorharen, kleine oren, puntige neus, kleine handen en voeten, en een rattenstaart). Deze transformatie heeft geen speleffecten.
Je hebt geen spiegelbeeld. Bijgelovige mensen die het opmerken denken dat je een vampier bent.
Je bent constant omringd door een kleine wolk vervelende maar onschadelijke vliegen.
table.name: Breaking a Contract; Breaking a Lesser Contract

table.caption: Fey Curses
rows: Je oren zijn op magische wijze vervangen door een paar zachte, pluizige ezelsoren. Bovendien, als je probeert te spreken, blaf je in plaats daarvan.
Je krijgt {@dice 1d3} levels van {@condition exhaustion}. Totdat de vloek eindigt, kunnen deze levels van {@condition exhaustion} niet verwijderd worden.
Spreuken kunnen je geen hit points teruggeven.
Het geluid van elfengelach vult je hoofd als je wakker bent en overstemt alle andere geluiden.
Alles wat je probeert op te pakken of in je handen houdt glipt door je vingers.
Maanlicht verbrandt je vlees. Je neemt {@damage 1d10} stralingsschade wanneer je je beurt in maanlicht begint.

Je wordt op magische wijze getransformeerd in een geanimeerde houten pop die op jou lijkt. Je statistieken zijn hetzelfde, maar je bent een Construct met kwetsbaarheid voor vuurschade, en je hebt geen lucht, voedsel of drinken nodig. Voorwerpen die je draagt of bij je draagt, blijven onaangetast.
Als je liegt, kun je {@dice 1d8} uur niet meer praten.
table.name: Fey Curses

table.caption: Ending the Curse
rows: Je moet je naam in een boom kerven, waarna de boom de magie van de vloek erft en sterft.
Je moet het bloed van een elfje of sprietje drinken terwijl je je koestert in het maanlicht.
Je moet de ware naam van het wezen dat je vervloekte drie keer achter elkaar uitspreken.
Terwijl je in het zonlicht op een boogbrug over stromend water staat, moet je de Zomerkoningin om haar "eerlijke zegen" smeken.
Nadat je je zakken gevuld hebt met dwaas goud, moet je met je armen wapperen en kwaken als een eend.
Je moet een beulskap (een zwarte paddenstoel die in de Feywild voorkomt) in de aarde begraven en er fluitend geitenmelk over gieten.
Je moet gebeten zijn door een feeëndraak. (Het is mogelijk dat elke feeëndraak volstaat, of dat de feeëndraak een bepaalde kleur moet hebben).
Je moet een boeket van acht zwarte rozen achterlaten op de plaats waar je vervloekt bent, of je moet het boeket geven aan het wezen dat je vervloekte.

Je moet een centaur overhalen om je acht mijl op zijn rug te dragen. Voordat de centaur dit vrijwillig zal doen, kan het zijn dat hij een geschenk of dienst in ruil vraagt, of de voltooiing van een queeste.
U moet bladeren of dennenappels van drie verschillende boomsoorten verzamelen en deze in een kampvuur bij volle maan verbranden terwijl u een bepaald kampvuurlied zingt.
Je moet een klein taartje bakken en het op de stoep van het verblijf van een boskabouter achterlaten. Pas als de kabouter de hele taart opeet, eindigt je vloek.
Je moet een ander wezen overhalen om vrijwillig jouw naam aan te nemen. Als het dat doet, erft het je vloek, waarna je naamloos bent en een nieuwe naam voor jezelf moet kiezen.
table.name: Fey Curses; Ending the Curse

table.caption: Fey Abodes

Een scheve stenen toren met een maanachtige lichtbol die rond zijn dak cirkelt, waardoor de schaduw van de toren als een wijzer van een klok beweegt
Een vervallen herenhuis dat gedeeltelijk verzonken is in het midden van een moeras
Een rotsachtige heuvel in de vorm van een slapende sater, waarvan de open mond de ingang van een grot vormt
Een windmolen die rondloopt op reusachtige kraaienpoten
Een afbrokkelende donjon op een klein eiland in het midden van een mistig loch
Een oude boerderij overgroeid met gigantische pompoenen
Een boomhut gebouwd in de takken van een boomklever
Een toren die vroeger de stam van een reusachtige {@condition petrified} boom was, met touwbruggen die hem verbinden met de reusachtige levende bomen die hem omringen
Een of meer huizen in uitgeholde paddestoelen
Een peperkoekhuisje met een met glazuur bedekt dak, ijspegels van glazuur, chocoladedeurtjes en gombastuintjes
Een muf, met web gehuld stenen huisje omringd door een boomgaard van ontwaakte appelbomen
Een wandelende stenen kolos met een toren als hoofd

Een ommuurde tuin vol vriendelijke beestjes, pratende bloemen en grijpgrage wijnstokken
Een goed bewaarde elfengraf begroeid met mos, versierd met beelden, en versierd met vogelnesten
Een herberg of pension uitgehouwen in de voet van een heuvel
Een drakenschedel liggend in het zand
Een of meer reusachtige roestige helmen die dienst doen als huizen, omringd door een oud slagveld
